metadata.case_name: Eleven clerical employees v. Corporation of Delhi

facts.text: Prior to 1948, Municipal Committee recruited matriculates and non-matriculates as clerks in junior grade of Rs. 35-2-65-3-95, offering Rs. 45 starting salary for graduates.

By resolution dated September 16, 1948, Committee revised grades: Rs. 55-3-85-4-125-5-130 for matriculates, Rs. 45-2-55-3-95-4-105 for non-matriculates; graduates in junior grade paid Rs. 20 p.m. graduate allowance, sanctioned by Chief Commissioner Memo No. F. 2(102)48-L.S.G. dated July 26/27, 1949.
Resolution No. 447 dated July 16, 1954 as amended by No. 550 dated July 30, 1954: Stopped graduate allowance to future recruits but continued for permanent/temporary employees already receiving it.
Thirty employees represented against confining allowance to existing recipients, demanding it for those passing B.A. after 1954 and new graduate recruits.
Resolution No. 693 dated November 1, 1957: Revived Rs. 20 p.m. personal pay to all graduates in junior grade, to obtain Chief Commissioner sanction.
Resolution No. 701 dated November 8, 1957: Amended No. 693 by deleting 'necessary sanction of the Chief Commissioner be obtained'.
Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 (Act 66 of 1957) replaced Municipal Committee with Municipal Corporation of Delhi.
Petitioners requested Commissioner to implement 1957 resolutions.

Office Order No. 1343 EST/58 dated November 5, 1958 by Commissioner: Admitted graduate allowance to 12 graduate junior grade clerks granted permission for higher studies before July 30, 1954; denied to remaining 18 petitioners.
Petitioners filed petition under Art. 226 before High Court of Punjab, withdrew it after ~5 years due to non-entertainability of joint petition.
Chief Commissioner order dated October 30, 1956 under s.232 Punjab Municipal Act, 1911: Prohibited municipal committees from revising pay scales, granting special pay or pecuniary benefits.
Petition filed under Art. 32 after ~5-year delay, explained by High Court pendency.

legal_issues.text: Whether Commissioner's order dated November 5, 1958 is discriminatory by excluding petitioners from graduate allowance while admitting claims of 12 others.
Whether Municipal Committee's resolutions dated November 1/8, 1957 reviving graduate allowance were valid given Chief Commissioner's order dated October 30, 1956.
Whether Chief Commissioner's order dated October 30, 1956 under s.232 Punjab Municipal Act was valid (authority, procedure under s.235, scope).

petitioner_arguments.text: Commissioner's order discriminatory as no rational basis for excluding petitioners from benefit of November 1/8, 1957 resolutions.
Resolutions of November 1/8, 1957 operative immediately, entitle graduates to Rs. 20 allowance retrospectively; no permission required for higher studies.
Chief Commissioner's order invalid: Beyond s.232 scope (only Deputy Commissioner, not prohibit passing resolutions, no anticipation, no s.235 opportunity); s.236 or s.42 applicable instead.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Municipal Act s.232, 235, 236, 42; precedents: Mistri Mohammad Hussain, Lahore Municipality v. Jagan Nath, Mahadeo Prasad

petitioner_arguments.text: Delay no bar to Art. 32 enforcement of fundamental right.

respondent_arguments.text: Commissioner's order without jurisdiction as Committee's resolutions invalid due to Chief Commissioner's prohibition under s.232; even admitted claims to 12 persons illegal; no discrimination.

court_reasoning.text: Delay not decided as petition fails on jurisdiction ground.

Chief Commissioner had authority under s.232 as adapted (Commissioner read as Chief Commissioner via Delhi Laws Act 1912, General Clauses Act); order prohibited acts like granting special pay, rendering resolutions invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prohibition of act implies no power to resolve to do it.

court_reasoning.text: Order anticipated acts as Committee was about to revise pay etc. before dissolution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Context of impending replacement by Corporation.

court_reasoning.text: S.235 inapplicable to Chief Commissioner's order (not subordinate authority); no requirement for affected parties' hearing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Committee could acquiesce; order effective immediately.

court_reasoning.text: S.232 and s.236 overlap but both available; s.42 not exclusive.
Resolutions ultra vires; Commissioner's order illegal ab initio; no discrimination.

holdings.text: Chief Commissioner's order dated October 30, 1956 valid under s.232; Committee's resolutions invalid.
No discrimination as Commissioner's order illegal for all.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mistri Mohammad Hussain v. Municipal Committee, Sialkot
precedents_cited.relevance: Suspension after act done; demolition not under s.172.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahadeo Prasad v. U. P. Government
precedents_cited.relevance: No anticipation under corresponding U.P. provision.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Gaffoor v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Opportunity required under Madras Act proviso; no analogue in Punjab Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition enforcing fundamental rights.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Municipal Act, 1911
statutes_cited.relevance: Chief Commissioner's power to prohibit acts/resolutions; procedure; conformity with law.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Laws Act, 1912
statutes_cited.relevance: Adaptation: Commissioner as State Government/Chief Commissioner.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of Central Government, State Government for Part C State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Relevant for State Government definition period.

outcome.summary: Petition dismissed as Committee's resolutions invalid due to valid prohibitory order by Chief Commissioner under s.232; Commissioner's order illegal for all, no discrimination.

key_quotes.text: "the order of the Chief Commissioner dated October 30, 1956 was perfectly legal and in view of that order it was not open to the Committee to sanction the payment of an allowance to any of its employees thereafter."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on invalidity of resolutions.

key_quotes.text: "when the doing of an act was prohibited the Committee ceased to have any power to do that act and a resolution passed by it to the effect that the act be done, can have no legal validity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains effect of prohibition under s.232.

key_quotes.text: "the order of the Commissioner dated November 5, 1958 being thus illegal no question of discrimination arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
